Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscale Surface Adsorption and Disordering in Battery Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: High-power lithium ion batteries have great potential for applications in electric vehicles or even electrical grid stabilization systems. Moreover, adopting plug-in hybrid electric vehicles for commuting in metropolitan areas can reduce CO2 emission by as much as 50%. While many conventional materials engineering techniques, such as carbon coating, doping, and particle size reduction, have been used to improve the performance of battery materials, meeting the grand challenges demands new transformative approaches. This project aims to develop an unconventional approach to use nanoscale 'surface phases' of self-regulating thickness to tailor battery materials to achieve superior properties that are not attainable by using the normal three-dimensional bulk materials or nanoparticles. This project also aims to bridge an important gap in the fundamental interfacial science by extending the well-established low-temperature surface science theories to high-temperature ceramic materials. Integrated research and education activities have impacts on high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, as well as the general public.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The research objectives of this project are twofold. The first (technological) objective is to develop a new method of using nanoscale 'surface phases' to improve the rate capability of battery materials. Compared with the conventional coatings, these 'surface phases' have several advantages: (a) they form spontaneously upon annealing as the thermodynamic equilibrium configurations; (b) they exhibit a self-selecting or "equilibrium" thickness that is tunable by changing thermodynamic potentials; and (c) surface doping can be introduced to increase the ionic and electronic conductivity, improve the morphological stability during electrochemical cycling, and suppress the formation of the detrimental thick solid-electrolyte interface layers. This new approach is expected to be applicable for engineering a wide variety of oxide based cathode materials (including many emerging materials), as well as some anode materials. The second (scientific) objective is to use battery materials as model systems to investigate a potentially transformative concept of utilizing nanoscale 'surface phases' to achieve properties unattainable through bulk phases, and to advance to the fundamental interfacial science by establishing new theories of high-temperature surface adsorption and disordering in ceramic materials. Broad impact activities include involving high school students in summer research programs; assembling a multidisciplinary undergraduate team to develop free-access online educational materials; and mentoring doctoral students in both cutting-edge energy-related research and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lithium-ion batteries have important applications in various portable devices, electric vehicles, and large-scale energy storage systems for enabling the use of wind and solar energies. This project developed the fundamental scientific understanding about the nanoscale surface adsorption and disordering in battery cathode and anode materials, which can be used to improve the capacity, rate capability, cycling stability, and safety of lithium-ion batteries via cost-effective and environmentally-friendly fabrication approaches. The fundamental oxide surface science developed in this project also has broad technological impacts on improving catalysts/photocatalysts, supercapacitors, and other functional materials for energy-related applications via surface engineering.   

Specifically, this NSF project demonstrated that a unique class of nanoscale surface amorphous films (SAFs) can form spontaneously on the electrode surfaces with a self-regulating (equilibrium) thickness on the order of one nanometer via a facile and generic “mixing and annealing” approach. These SAFs, as a unique class of surface phases (also called "complexions"), can be used to simultaneously improve the rate capability, cycling stability, and safety of a variety of anode and cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Other types of surface complexions can also form and be used to improve the electrochemical performance of battery materials. In this project, five cases of substantial improvements of battery cathode and anode materials via surface (complexion) engineering have been shown. This NSF project further demonstrated the broad technological impacts of this novel surface engineering method beyond lithium-ion batteries, in areas like photocatalysts, supercapacitors, and fast oxygen-ion conductors, as well as controlling the growth and defects of nanomaterials.

The successful completion of this NSF project established a transformative idea of utilizing the spontaneously-formed nanoscale "interfacial phases" to achieve superior properties that are unattainable by using conventional bulk phases or nanomaterials. 

In the areas of education and outreach, this NSF project has involved and educated fifteen (15) undergraduate researchers and three (3) high school students, in addition to training graduate students. The principle investigator and PhD students working on this project also hosted lab tours during the UCSD Engineering Exploration Day to introduce this NSF project and related research facilities to community high school and middle school students with diversifying background.
